intro: Microglossa sessilifolia, commonly known as the sessile-leaved microglossa, is a small, herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central and South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes caraway and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, greenish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or well-drained soils at elevations ranging from 1,500 to 3,000 meters. Its leaves are sessile, meaning they attach directly to the stem without a stalk, and are often covered in fine hairs. Microglossa sessilifolia is generally short-lived and is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
